{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3412241,"name":"Ashton Demmer","username":"ashtondemmer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ashtondemmer/{size}/230987_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T03:03:57.253Z","cooked":"

We’re working on implementing auto alignment for amp, chain, etc… We’re using pathplanners pathfinding abilities which is working well (drives from point A to point B while avoiding obstacles). However, the path just gets the robot close to the end pose and then stops the path. Is there a way to set a tolerance through pathplanner so it won’t abort the auto early? If not, is the best route just profiled pid controllers for fine tuning the X, Y, theta?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T03:08:28.621Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":567,"reads":327,"readers_count":326,"score":2900.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":469354,"topic_slug":"auto-align-using-pathfinding","display_username":"Ashton Demmer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51932,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6147 - Tonkabots"},"post_url":"/t/auto-align-using-pathfinding/469354/1","custom_user_title":"6147 - Tonkabots","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3412244,"name":"Yishai Levy","username":"levyishai","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/levyishai/{size}/264719_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T03:18:35.054Z","cooked":"
ashtondemmer:

If not, is the best route just profiled pid controllers for fine tuning the X, Y, theta?

What we found best is doing that (though without a profile, small error like this usually doesn’t need one), or creating an “on the fly” path for bigger error (more than 0.25m)

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T03:18:50.798Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":321,"readers_count":320,"score":99.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":469354,"topic_slug":"auto-align-using-pathfinding","display_username":"Yishai Levy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57809,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team Captain, Programming Lead & Operator"},"post_url":"/t/auto-align-using-pathfinding/469354/2","custom_user_title":"Team Captain, Programming Lead & Operator","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412248,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T03:33:05.428Z","cooked":"
ashtondemmer:

Is there a way to set a tolerance through pathplanner so it won’t abort the auto early? If not, is the best route just profiled pid controllers for fine tuning the X, Y, theta?

The tolerance is the size of a navigation grid node. While you could make a navigation grid with smaller nodes, it is going to be better to follow the pathfindToPose command with your own “driveToPose” command (as you postulate) to take care of the final alignment. There should not be any obstacles in the way for the last few inches.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T03:33:05.428Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":80.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":469354,"topic_slug":"auto-align-using-pathfinding","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/auto-align-using-pathfinding/469354/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412282,"name":"sam liu","username":"catrix","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T07:13:12.994Z","cooked":"
ashtondemmer:

We’re using pathplanners pathfinding abilities

I assume that refers to AutoBuilder.pathfindToPose(), please correct me if I’m wrong.

ashtondemmer:

Is there a way to set a tolerance through pathplanner so it won’t abort the auto early?

No, because if you are not path-finding to the start of a trajectory, path-planner only cares about how many seconds have elapsed.

// com.pathplanner.lib.commands.PathfindingCommand.java
@Override
public boolean isFinished() {
  if (finish) {
    return true;
  }

  if (targetPath != null && !targetPath.isChoreoPath()) {
    ...
  }

  if (currentTrajectory != null) {
    return timer.hasElapsed(currentTrajectory.getTotalTimeSeconds() - timeOffset);
  }

  return false;
}

My Suggestion

Although you can’t do precise auto-alignment using the path-finding command alone, you can divide the auto-alignment process to two steps:

  1. path-find to roughly get to the position
  2. perform a precise auto-align

This is how I would implement it:

public class AutoAlignment extends SequentialCommandGroup {
    /**
     * creates a precise auto-alignment command
     * NOTE: AutoBuilder must be configured!
     * the command has two steps:
     * 1. path-find to the target pose, roughly
     * 2. accurate auto alignment
     * */
    public AutoAlignment(
            PathConstraints constraints,
            HolonomicDriveController holonomicDriveController,
            Supplier<Pose2d> robotPoseSupplier,
            Consumer<ChassisSpeeds> robotRelativeSpeedsOutput,
            Subsystem driveSubsystem,
            Pose2d targetPose
    ) {
        /* tolerance for the precise approach */
        holonomicDriveController.setTolerance(new Pose2d(0.05, 0.05, Rotation2d.fromDegrees(5)));
        final Command
                pathFindToTargetRough = AutoBuilder.pathfindToPose(targetPose, constraints, 0.5),
                preciseAlignment = new FunctionalCommand(
                        () -> {},
                        () -> robotRelativeSpeedsOutput.accept(holonomicDriveController.calculate(
                                robotPoseSupplier.get(),
                                targetPose,
                                0,
                                targetPose.getRotation()
                        )),
                        (interrupted) ->
                                robotRelativeSpeedsOutput.accept(new ChassisSpeeds()),
                        holonomicDriveController::atReference
                        );

        super.addCommands(pathFindToTargetRough);
        super.addCommands(preciseAlignment);

        super.addRequirements(driveSubsystem);
    }
}

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T08:54:11.155Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":195,"readers_count":194,"score":49.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":469354,"topic_slug":"auto-align-using-pathfinding","display_username":"sam liu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HjQfurIPfgw","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":60}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60033,"username":"catrix","name":"sam liu","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60033,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CE Student @ UWaterloo | 5516 Alum "},"post_url":"/t/auto-align-using-pathfinding/469354/5","custom_user_title":"CE Student @ UWaterloo | 5516 Alum ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412361,"name":"Joe Witcpalek","username":"wits","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wits/{size}/110752_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T17:52:54.558Z","cooked":"

I’d look at a couple of different things:

  1. Does current pose match the end pose of the path?
  • If yes, are there things affecting your current pose’s accuracy (wheel slippage, bumped something, bad vision update, etc. could affect your current pose). Is the end point of the path accurate (should be roughly half the robot in that direction + bumper thickness set back from say the AMP).
  • If no, may need to look at PID controller gains and increase them (maybe your sending too small of a voltage when the error gets small).
  1. Did you time out?
  • If yes, look at the PID controller gains (might need to be more aggressive) and the path constraints, can the robot actually meet them?

PID gains, for us at least, were the biggest issue. What we do to tune this is create a path that does a 1M x 1M square changing the heading as turn the corner and tune the gains such that we hit each corner correctly. Then, the robot tends to follow the path pretty closely.

Also, how hard is it to implement the simulation code you used? It would be super helpful for debugging at home…

What I had set up was pathfind and then follow path. AutoBuilder.pathfindThenFollowPath(PathPlannerPath.fromPathFile("short path to pose here"),pathConstraints); This allows you to also fine-tune how the robot approaches the target pose, and allows you to control the heading.

Not OP but they did and ngl it’s awesome
Here’s the original thread

Java Robot Code Simulation with Physics Engine Programming
Hey everyone! I’m the programmer of Team 5516 “Iron Maple”. Our team has developed an all-real robot simulation and we are happy to share our progress! Previous FRC simulators like MoSimulator run on game engines and are separate from the actual robot code. In contrast, our simulator is entirely embedded in the Java robot code and has the same operating logic as the real robot. [robot physics simulation] It runs directly on WPISim and renders the image using AdvantageScope. We used dyn4j, …

It took us about 500 lines of code, but we plan to make it a public project so other teams can use it, you can take a look at this post

Java Robot Code Simulation with Physics Engine Programming
Hey everyone! I’m the programmer of Team 5516 “Iron Maple”. Our team has developed an all-real robot simulation and we are happy to share our progress! Previous FRC simulators like MoSimulator run on game engines and are separate from the actual robot code. In contrast, our simulator is entirely embedded in the Java robot code and has the same operating logic as the real robot. [robot physics simulation] It runs directly on WPISim and renders the image using AdvantageScope. We used dyn4j, …

our code is here Shenzhen-Robotics-Alliance/Maple-Swerve-Skeleton: Iron Maple’s swerve-drive skeleton project, based on 6328’s Advanced Swerve Drive Example (github.com)
